name: Anti-Oppressive Major Arcana
description: A Major Arcana tarot deck examining interlocking oppressions in social work history through inverse visibility metrics

methodology.source_text: Chapman & Withers (2019). A Violent History of Benevolence
methodology.core_principle: All figures are complicit. No moral judgments. Reflection on complicity, not identification with innocence.

historical_figure.name: Aaron 'Pa' Carvery
historical_figure.context: Final holdout in Africville, refusing to leave until 1970

sections.standard_meaning: New beginnings, innocence, spontaneity, free spirit
sections.critical_meaning: The journey's beginning and end. Innocence that is not innocent—the fool who sees what others refuse to see.
sections.reflection_prompt: What does it mean to hold ground when the world insists you move?

historical_figure.name: Maggie L. Walker
historical_figure.context: Founded St. Luke Penny Savings Bank—first woman bank president in America

sections.critical_meaning: Transformative action within hostile systems. Made something from nothing when systems refused to recognize her resources.
sections.reflection_prompt: What resources do you have that systems refuse to recognize?

historical_figure.name: Elizabeth Williams Shadd Shreve
historical_figure.context: Circuit-riding missionary in Buxton fugitive settlement

sections.standard_meaning: Intuition, sacred knowledge, divine feminine, the subconscious
sections.critical_meaning: Hidden knowledge, keeper of paths and secrets. Nearly invisible to history while sustaining community survival.
sections.reflection_prompt: Whose knowledge sustains communities while remaining unwritten?

historical_figure.name: Janie Porter Barrett
historical_figure.context: Founded first Black settlement house in Virginia from her own home

sections.critical_meaning: Creation that grows from home. Built institutions that sustained community life without institutional recognition.
sections.reflection_prompt: What grows from care that refuses institutional recognition?

historical_figure.name: Mary Richmond
historical_figure.context: Created 'scientific casework'—the architecture of professional social control

sections.critical_meaning: The father-energy of professional social control. Structure that becomes surveillance dressed as help.
sections.reflection_prompt: When does structure become a cage? When does help become control?

historical_figure.name: Jane Addams
historical_figure.context: Nobel laureate, Hull-House founder, eugenics supporter

sections.standard_meaning: Spiritual wisdom, religious beliefs, conformity, tradition
sections.critical_meaning: High morals firmly embedded in colonial institutions. The priest who blesses the empire while believing in reform.
sections.reflection_prompt: What violences hide behind moral authority?

historical_figure.name: Henry Bibb
historical_figure.context: Escaped slavery multiple times trying to free his family. Founded Voice of the Fugitive.

sections.standard_meaning: Love, harmony, relationships, values alignment, choices
sections.critical_meaning: Love as revolutionary force and impossible choice. What would you risk everything to return to?
sections.reflection_prompt: What would you risk everything to return to?

historical_figure.name: Claudette Colvin
historical_figure.context: At 15, refused to give up her bus seat—nine months before Rosa Parks

sections.critical_meaning: Moved forward when told to move back. Determination that history chose not to remember.
sections.reflection_prompt: Whose determination is remembered? Whose is erased?

historical_figure.name: Ida B. Wells
historical_figure.context: Anti-lynching crusader who documented terror when doing so meant death threats

sections.critical_meaning: Strength that speaks truth to murderous power. Courage that costs everything and persists.
sections.reflection_prompt: What truth requires courage to speak in your context?

historical_figure.name: Reverdy Cassius Ransom
historical_figure.context: AME Bishop who brought social gospel to Black churches

sections.critical_meaning: Light held up in institutional darkness. Wisdom that comes from standing apart from mainstream success.
sections.reflection_prompt: What wisdom comes from standing apart from mainstream success?

historical_figure.name: Oscar McCulloch
historical_figure.context: His 'Tribe of Ishmael' study launched eugenic policy—then he changed his mind, too late

sections.standard_meaning: Good luck, karma, life cycles, destiny, turning point
sections.critical_meaning: The wheel that crushes those it claims to study. Cycles of harm that continue from research done with good intentions.
sections.reflection_prompt: What cycles of harm continue from research done with good intentions?

historical_figure.name: George Edmund Haynes
historical_figure.context: First Black PhD from Columbia, co-founded Urban League

sections.standard_meaning: Justice, fairness, truth, cause and effect, law
sections.critical_meaning: Built institutions to address systemic inequality within systems that created it. Can justice be built within unjust institutions?
sections.reflection_prompt: Can justice be built within unjust institutions?

historical_figure.name: Zaynab al-Ghazali
historical_figure.context: Imprisoned and tortured for organizing. Founded Muslim Women's Association.

sections.standard_meaning: Pause, surrender, letting go, new perspectives
sections.critical_meaning: Surrendered to a vision that cost everything. What becomes visible only from a position of suspension?
sections.reflection_prompt: What becomes visible only from a position of surrender?

historical_figure.name: Albert Rose
historical_figure.context: Wrote the report that destroyed Africville. Called Regent Park a failure.

sections.critical_meaning: The professional who signs death warrants for communities. What dies when experts decide communities must be 'renewed'?
sections.reflection_prompt: What dies when experts decide communities must be 'renewed'?

historical_figure.name: Booker T. Washington
historical_figure.context: Accommodation politics—the middle path that critics called complicity

sections.critical_meaning: Patience that some saw as wisdom, others as surrender. The middle path within impossible conditions.
sections.reflection_prompt: When is patience wisdom? When is it collaboration with oppression?

historical_figure.name: Richard Henry Pratt
historical_figure.context: 'Kill the Indian, save the man.' Founded Carlisle Indian School.

sections.critical_meaning: The shadow that calls itself salvation. Bondage that presents itself as education, as help, as love.
sections.reflection_prompt: What bondage presents itself as education? As help?

historical_figure.name: John Edward Lloyd
historical_figure.context: Halifax Mayor during Africville destruction. 'Sometimes people need to be shown what's in their best interests.'

sections.standard_meaning: Sudden change, upheaval, chaos, revelation, awakening
sections.critical_meaning: The tower falls on those inside while those outside call it progress. Whose structures must fall?
sections.reflection_prompt: Whose towers are destroyed? Who decides which structures must fall?

historical_figure.name: Mary Ann Shadd Cary
historical_figure.context: First Black woman newspaper editor in North America. Voice of the fugitive.

sections.critical_meaning: Star that guided the way north. Hope that sustains when the journey has no guaranteed end.
sections.reflection_prompt: What hope sustains when the journey has no guaranteed end?

historical_figure.name: Katherine Bement Davis
historical_figure.context: Led eugenic criminology, built Bedford Hills to confine 'defective' women for life

sections.critical_meaning: Science as shadow, reform as nightmare. Fears that drive policies claiming to be rational.
sections.reflection_prompt: What fears drive policies that claim to be rational?

historical_figure.name: Viola Desmond
historical_figure.context: Sat in the whites-only section in Nova Scotia, 1946. Now on the Canadian $10 bill.

sections.critical_meaning: Light that refused to be dimmed. Joy as an act of resistance.
sections.reflection_prompt: What joy is an act of resistance?

historical_figure.name: Josephine Shaw Lowell
historical_figure.context: COS founder who led eugenic criminology while supporting labor rights

sections.critical_meaning: The call to account that implicates the judge. How do we reckon with those who did both harm and good?
sections.reflection_prompt: How do we reckon with those who did both harm and good?

historical_figure.name: Philip C. Garrett
historical_figure.context: Chaired the 1892 conference where Pratt spoke. Nearly invisible now.

sections.critical_meaning: The world that was built on erased foundations. Whose completion required whose erasure?
sections.reflection_prompt: What world is complete? Whose completion required whose erasure?

attribution.source: Chapman, C., & Withers, A. J. (2019). A Violent History of Benevolence: Interlocking oppression in the moral economies of social working. University of Toronto Press.
